record.attribute:
We are pleased to announce the release of ClinEpiDB 5!

New Features in this Release

  • The analysis apps in the 'Analyze Results' tab of the results table have now been upated. There are still three apps available, Distributions, Contingency Tables, and Data Summaries but they have been redesigned to be easier to navigate and view results! Check them out!

New Data in this Release

  • The Global Enteric Multicenter Study (GEMS), coordinated by the University of Maryland School of Medicineâ€™s Center for Vaccine Development, was a case-control study conducted at seven diverse, high-burden sites in Asia and Africa: the Gambia, Kenya, Mali, Mozambique, Bangladesh, India and Pakistan. The study enrolled 22,568 children under 5 years of age. GEMS is the largest, most comprehensive study of childhood diarrheal diseases ever conducted in developing country settings. Results showed that most attributable cases of moderate-to-severe diarrhea were due to four pathogens: rotavirus, Cryptosporidium, enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli producing heat-stable toxin (ST-ETEC; with or without co-expression of heat-labile enterotoxin), and Shigella. Truly a groundbreaking study in childhood infectious disease, the initial GEMS1 Case-Control data, including TaqMan Array Card molecular detection results, are now available on ClinEpiDB.org. Exploring the data using the search wizard and analysis applications are open to all users; in order to download the data, investigators will be required to register and submit a data access request. About 1000 stool samples from GEMS1 have 16S sequence data available; results and more information about those samples can be found at our companion site MicrobiomeDB.org. In the coming months, the GEMS1A and heathcare utilization surveys that were conducted in concert with GEMS will also be made available.

ASTMH 2018 New Orleans

The EuPathDB and ClinEpiDB team will be attending the American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene annual meeting this month, kicking off Sunday, October 28th, 2018! We are looking forward to chatting with the attendees. ClinEpiDB and EuPathDB will be sharing booth 317-319 with VectorBase. Stop by for a demo, learn more about ClinEpiDB, and grab a sticker!

We are pleased to announce the release of ClinEpiDB 4!

New Features in this Release

  • A News section and Twitter newsfeed have been added to our homepage to make update announcements easily accessible.
  • We have improved the layout and design of our analysis apps. The new format allows for easier variable selection, more-intuitive layout and figure presentation. We have also added to the number of facets or strata that can be selected for the data.
  • Protecting the data of research investigators and study participants is important to us. We have updated our 'Data Access and Use Policy' to reflect the different levels of data access offered to data providers and users. Please contact us for more information about how data access restrictions are implemented on ClinEpiDB.
  • In our 'Tutorials and Resources' section we have added a document that provides quick guidance for researchers when considering the complete lifecycle of data. It includes links to data sharing resources and some template language for putting together consent forms, IRB proposals, and amendments.

New Data in this Release

  • New data has been added to the PRISM cohort study. Participants from Nagongera were followed for another year from July 1, 2016 to June 30, 2017. This addition to the dataset includes a few new participants, thousands of new observations, and new light trap data.

We are pleased to announce the release of ClinEpiDB 3

New Features in this Release

  • A new tutorial explains the three analysis apps available in ClinEpiDB after returning search results. These include distributions, contingency tables, and data summarization statistics.
  • For each study that will be represented in ClinEpiDB there will be a detailed study data set page. Here you will find information about the study that will be necessary to accurately interpret the data including key details like study design, data collection methodology and a description of the population of interest. For PRISM, in this release we have added data collection materials (Case Report Forms) and data dictionaries.

No new Data in this Release

We are pleased to announce the release of ClinEpiDB 2

New Features in this Release

  • A new tutorial explains the options ClinEpiDB provides to explore results after performing a search. These include the dynamic tabular outputs, column visualization tools, and data download options.
  • In the Distributions app we have added automatically generated summary statistics: mean, median, range, SD (standard deviation) & interquartile range (IQR)
  • Improvements to our axis labels in our analysis apps
  • Implementation of indicators of available data. Filters are now annotated with eg. 1 of 44,508 Observations have no data provided for this filter.
  • Improvements to Active Filters summary popup describing more clearly filter selections, especially in the Related Observations step.

No new Data in this Release

We are pleased to announce the first release of ClinEpiDB

This release of ClinEpiDB contains data from the Program for Resistance, Immunology, Surveillance and Modeling of Malaria in Uganda (PRISM) study. PRISM is the dedicated East Africa International Center of Excellence for Malaria Research. The data presented here include the longitudinal cohort and entomological surveillance components of the PRISM study.

New Features in this Release

  • The contingency table app allows you to create 2x2 contingency tables of different categorical variables or allows you to create categorical variables from continuous measurements. Here you can explore the relationship between two variables.
  • The data summary app for longitudinal datasets, allows you to plot summary information, similar to a box-and-whisker plot for variables over time. The timeline(s) allow you to filter by time periods and age groups of interest.
  • The Distributions app allows you to visualize histograms of available variables and then facet or stratify these distributions by additional variablaes.
